docs.lead_paragraph: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about Wednesday:
docs.snippet: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about Wednesday:

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of uninsured U.S. residents fell by more than 11 million since President Barack Obama signed the health care overhaul five years ago, according to a pair of reports Tuesday from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: CDC: Uninsured Drop by 11M Since Passage of Obama's Law
headline.print_headline: CDC: Uninsured Drop by 11M Since Passage of Obama's Law

docs.snippet: The number of uninsured U.S. residents fell by more than 11 million since President Barack Obama signed the health care overhaul five years ago, according to a pair of reports Tuesday from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

docs.lead_paragraph: Half of the households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums last year under the Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to the federal government, according to a new analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

headline.main: Many Will Need to Repay Health Subsidies
headline.print_headline: Many Will Need to Repay Portion of Health Subsidies

docs.abstract: Analysis by Kaiser Family Foundation finds that half of households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums in 2014 under Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to federal government.
docs.snippet: Half of the households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums last year under the Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to the federal government, according to a new analysis by the Kaiser Family...

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The pattern so far suggests a challenge in reaching the goal of enrolling 10 million more eligible people within the next few years.

headline.main: Now the Hard Part: The Rate of Health Care Enrollment Seems Set to Slow
headline.print_headline: Analysts Fear That Health Care Enrollment Will Slow

docs.abstract: The Upshot; analysts worry that patterns suggest future enrollment in state-run health exchange marketplaces may be sluggish; trend may indicate ongoing confusion about how Affordable Care Act works, or may presage further difficulty in getting people to sign up for health insurance.
docs.snippet: The pattern so far suggests a challenge in reaching the goal of enrolling 10 million more eligible people within the next few years.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz’s speech announcing his 2016 presidential campaign captured so many Republican paradoxes and idiocies, especially on immigration and health care.
docs.abstract: Editorial argues that substance of Sen Ted Cruz's speech at Liberty University, in which he announced that he is running for 2016 Republican presidential nomination, is at odds with reality; suggests that Cruz's federalist views are incoherent; welcomes fact that Cruz will serve in Republican primary to illustrate many of the paradoxes and idiocies that party must sort out before election.
docs.snippet: Senator Ted Cruz’s speech announcing his 2016 presidential campaign captured so many Republican paradoxes and idiocies, especially on immigration and health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New Mexico case highlighted how unsubstantiated notions like the health dangers of electromagnetic signals can continue to get a serious hearing.

headline.main: When Science Is Lost in a Legal Maze
headline.print_headline: Science, Lost in a Legal Maze

docs.abstract: Case in which Santa Fe, NM, man Arthur Firstenberg sued neighbor, alleging that electromagnetic radiation from her use of cellphones and Wi-Fi connection damaged his health, illustrates sometimes fraught relationship between legal system and sound science; Firstenberg's allegations are not backed up by science but lawsuit has resulted in hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal fees.
docs.snippet: A New Mexico case highlighted how unsubstantiated notions like the health dangers of electromagnetic signals can continue to get a serious hearing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing or containing Medicare and Medicaid prices can put downward pressure on the prices hospitals can charge to all customers.

headline.main: Hospitals Are Wrong About Shifting Costs to Private Insurers

docs.snippet: Reducing or containing Medicare and Medicaid prices can put downward pressure on the prices hospitals can charge to all customers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Language has been added to an emerging bipartisan deal on Medicare clarifying that the agreement's abortion restrictions on community health centers are temporary and won't be inscribed into permanent law, House Democrats said Monday.

headline.main: House Dems Say New Abortion Language Helps Medicare Doc Deal
headline.print_headline: House Dems Say New Abortion Language Helps Medicare Doc Deal

docs.snippet: Language has been added to an emerging bipartisan deal on Medicare clarifying that the agreement's abortion restrictions on community health centers are temporary and won't be inscribed into permanent law, House Democrats said Monday.
